case_vignette: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician with an ongoing pruritic rash for 1 week. The rash is on his right forearm (refer to the image). He has not had a similar rash in the past. He has no history of allergies, and he is not taking any medications. He frequently enjoys gardening in their backyard. They have no household pets. The physical examination reveals no other abnormalities.
question: Given the most likely diagnosis, which  is the most appropriate treatment of the condition described in this case?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got this itchy rash on my right forearm that's been there for a week.
What does the rash look like?
It looks like the one in the picture you're referring to.
I'm sorry, but I'm not able to view pictures. Can you describe the rash for me?
Oh, sorry about that – it's red and bumpy.
Have you noticed if the rash becomes worse with certain activities or after eating certain foods?
No, it doesn't seem to get worse with any specific activities or foods.
Have you started using any new soaps, lotions, or detergents recently?
No, I haven't started using any new soaps, lotions, or detergents.
Have you been exposed to any plants, animals, or chemicals that you can recall?
Yes, I frequently enjoy gardening in our backyard.
Do you remember coming into contact with any specific plants that you haven't been exposed to before?
I don't recall touching any new plants that I haven't been exposed to before.
Have you experienced any fever or joint pains along with the rash?
No, I haven't had any fever or joint pains.
Do you have any known allergies?
No, I don't have any known allergies.
Have you tried any treatments or taken any medications for the rash? If so, what were they?
No, I haven't tried any treatments or taken any medications for it.
Is the rash localized only on your forearm, or has it spread to other areas of your body?
The rash is only on my right forearm.
Does the rash fluid-filled blisters, or is it just red and bumpy?
It's just red and bumpy.
Has anyone in your family experienced a similar rash or any skin conditions?
No, nobody in my family has had a similar rash or skin conditions.
Is the rash oozing any fluid or bleeding?
No, the rash isn't oozing any fluid or bleeding.
Final Diagnosis: Contact dermatitis.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with an itchy rash on their right forearm that has been present for a week. The rash is red and bumpy and does not seem to worsen with specific activities or foods. The patient denies using any new soaps, lotions, or detergents and enjoys gardening in their backyard, but has not touched any new plants. trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is contact dermatitis, and the most appropriate treatment is topical corticosteroids and avoidance of the allergen or irritant causing the rash.
